Expectation1: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation1: They have a generous deadline and can refactor the module later
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: I stare at my screen, fingers poised above the keyboard, the lines of code for the new module half-finished. The deadline isn’t pressing, and I know I should take this chance to refactor the messy parts, make the code something I can be proud of—clean, efficient, easy for my teammates to understand. But a notification pops up: the online candidate forum for my district is starting. I’ve promised myself to be a better citizen, to stay informed, to participate, to give feedback that might actually matter. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in. My team expects quality work, and I want to deliver. But my community expects engagement, and I want to be the kind of person who shows up. My mind races, torn between the satisfaction of perfecting my code and the responsibility of being present for my city’s future. I hover between tabs, heart pounding, knowing I can’t do both at once.
